What Slack improved in its onboarding:
https://www.appcues.com/blog/slack-user-onboarding-experience/

This is the old one, but probably there are still good ideas to take from it:
http://www.useronboard.com/how-slack-onboards-new-users/

I found the 5th point of 2nd link interesting.
Placed mission critical information upfront
Slack previously used “hotspots” to introduce users to important UI elements. These hotspots would pulse until a user clicked on them, then disappear once the user had read the tip.
The hotspots from the old onboarding experience are a nice way of providing users the contextual guidance they need in an unintrusive manner. They allow users to consume information when they are ready to rather than making it a prescriptive part of the experience.
Their click rates, however, can be low. So when you have mission critical information that a user must know to be successful, sequential hotspots are the pattern of choice.

I just made an account on a Discourse instance for the first time. It's a discussion system (more "forum" than "chat"), with a bunch of things they want you to know to get the most out of it, so they have an interactive onboarding bot. It was pretty good!

I recommend trying out the experience live -- it took me 5m -- by making an account at https://try.discourse.org/.

Among the neat things it did:

  • Step by step the bot asked me to try a thing, then I did it, and it replied. It sounded throughout like a super-friendly encouraging coach-human.
  • Some of the things were replying to it (to try out markup features). Others were other actions in the app -- so it needed some magic to know when I did those.
